Control Algorithm Design

⇑\Uparrow\quad⇑Control Framework of StarlETH

⇑\Uparrow\quad⇑MIT Mini Cheetch Control Framework

The framework for JUN-GO is not clear now. But there are two good references from MIT mini cheetch and StarlETH. Through the summary about the above framework, we can divide the control framework into the following levels according to algorithm complexity, control frequency, etc.

Top-level:

Mid-level:

Low-level:

Low-level controller can also be called joint-level control which is used to make the response of motor correspond to the control command sent to the motor.

Usually, for the stance feet, we use torque control. And for the swing feet, we use position control.[1]

Now, the low level controllers for JUN-GO are embedded in the motor. But it can only implement the mode of current / velocity / position.

Luckily, we can use experiment to get the current constant of motor and use current mode to achieve the equivalent effect with open-loop torque mode. But if we want to get better torque control accuracy, using SEA(Series elastic actuator)[2] will be a better choice.

Moreover, although we have successfully used the inverse kinematics and position mode to achieve the trot gait on JUN-GO. But maybe there is a better method to optimize the effect of motor. For example, we can add velocity feedforward to achieve better control accuracy and reduce the requirement of the bandwith. But the drawback is obvious, that's we need to move the low-level contoller from the micro-controller in the motor to our MCU.

[1]: Control of Dynamic Gaits for a Quadrupedal Robot
[2]: A Low Cost Modular Actuator for Dynamic

Kinematics

For the forward kinematics of the quadruped robot, we will use Denavit-Hartenberg Representation.

The main content of use Denavit-Hartenberg Representation is:

  • All joints will be represented by z-axis. If the joint is revolute, the z-axis is in the direction of rotation as followed by the right-hand rule. And the rotation about the z-axis (θ\thetaθ) is the joint variable. And the index number for the z-axis of joint n+1n+1n+1 is znz_nzn​.

  • The direction of xnx_nxn​ will be along the common normal between zn−1z_{n-1}zn−1​ and znz_nzn​.

    • If two z-axes are parallel, We will pick the common normal that is colinear with the common normal of the previous joint.
    • If two z-axes are intersecting, we will assign the x-axis along the direction of the cross-product of the two z-axes.

Four parameter in D-H Representation:

  • θ\thetaθ represents a rotation about the zzz-axis
  • ddd represents the distance on the zzz-axis between two successive common normals (or joint offset)
  • aaa represents the length of each common normal (the length of a link)
  • α\alphaα represents the angle between two successive z-axes (also called joint twist angle). Commonly, only θ\thetaθ and ddd are joint variables.

The steps of necessary motions to transform from one reference frame to the next:

  1. Rotate about the znz_nzn​-axis an angle of θn+1\theta_{n+1}θn+1​ to make xnx_nxn​ and xn+1x_{n+1}xn+1​ parallel to each other.
  2. Translate along the znz_nzn​-axis a distance of dn+1d_{n+1}dn+1​ to make xnx_nxn​ and xn+1x_{n+1}xn+1​ colinear.
  3. Translate along the (already rotated) xnx_nxn​-axis a distance of an+1a_{n+1}an+1​ to bring the origins of xnx_nxn​ and xn+1x_{n+1}xn+1​ together. At this point, the origins of the two reference frames will be at the same location.
  4. Rotate znz_nzn​-axis about xn+1x_{n+1}xn+1​-axis an angle of αn+1\alpha_{n+1}αn+1​ to align znz_nzn​-axis with zn+1z_{n+1}zn+1​-axis. At this point, frames nnn and n+1n+1n+1 will be exactly the same.

The transformation nTn+1^nT_{n+1}nTn+1​ (called An+1A_{n+1}An+1​) between two successive frames representing the preceding four movements is the product of the four matrices representing them. Since all transformations are relative to the current frame (they are measured and performed relative to the axes of the current local frame), all matrices are post-multiplied. The result is:

nTn+1=An+1=Rot(z,θn+1)×Trans(0,0,dn+1)×Trans(an+1,0)×Rot(x,αn+1)=[Cθn+1−Sθn+1Cαn+1Sθn+1Sαn+1an+1Cθn+1Sθn+1Cθn+1Cαn+1−Cθn+1Sαn+1an+1Sθn+10Sαn+1Cαn+1dn+10001]\begin{aligned} ^nT_{n+1} = A_{n+1} &= Rot(z,\theta_{n+1})\times Trans(0,0,d_{n+1})\times Trans(a_{n+1},0)\times Rot(x,\alpha_{n+1})\\ &= \left[ \begin{matrix} C\theta_{n+1} & -S\theta_{n+1}C\alpha_{n+1} & S\theta_{n+1}S\alpha_{n+1} & a_{n+1}C\theta_{n+1}\\ S\theta_{n+1} & C\theta_{n+1}C\alpha_{n+1} & -C\theta_{n+1}S\alpha_{n+1} & a_{n+1}S\theta_{n+1}\\ 0 & S\alpha_{n+1} & C\alpha_{n+1} & d_{n+1}\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned}nTn+1​=An+1​​=Rot(z,θn+1​)×Trans(0,0,dn+1​)×Trans(an+1​,0)×Rot(x,αn+1​)=⎣⎢⎢⎡​Cθn+1​Sθn+1​00​−Sθn+1​Cαn+1​Cθn+1​Cαn+1​Sαn+1​0​Sθn+1​Sαn+1​−Cθn+1​Sαn+1​Cαn+1​0​an+1​Cθn+1​an+1​Sθn+1​dn+1​1​⎦⎥⎥⎤​​

For convinence, we can write the D-H parameters into a table. With that we can get the transformation matrix between joints easily.

# θ\thetaθ ddd aaa α\alphaα
0−10-10−1
1−21-21−2
2−32-32−3
3−43-43−4
4−54-54−5
5−65-65−6

e.g. For a 2-DoF robot, there will be 2 joints(Joint1, Joint2). And there will be 3 coordinates(z0z_0z0​, z1z_1z1​, zHz_HzH​) fixed on the arm.

−pz=ρ′sinϕ′sinθ2+ρ′cosϕ′cosθ2-p_z = \rho'sin\phi'sin\theta_2 + \rho'cos\phi'cos\theta_2 −pz​=ρ′sinϕ′sinθ2​+ρ′cosϕ′cosθ2​

−pz=ρ′cos(ϕ′−θ2)-p_z = \rho'cos(\phi'-\theta_2) −pz​=ρ′cos(ϕ′−θ2​)

ρ′=(a1+a2C3)2+(a2S3)2ϕ′=arctan2(a1+a2C3,a2S3)cos(ϕ′−θ2)=pzρ′sin(ϕ′−θ2)=±1−pzρ2\begin{array}{cc} \rho'=\sqrt{(a_1+a_2C_3)^2+(a_2S_3)^2} & \phi'=arctan2(a_1 + a_2C_3, a_2S_3)\\ cos(\phi'-\theta_2)=\dfrac{p_z}{\rho'} & sin(\phi'-\theta_2)=\pm\sqrt{1-\dfrac{p_z}{\rho}^2} \end{array}ρ′=(a1​+a2​C3​)2+(a2​S3​)2​cos(ϕ′−θ2​)=ρ′pz​​​ϕ′=arctan2(a1​+a2​C3​,a2​S3​)sin(ϕ′−θ2​)=±1−ρpz​​2​​

ϕ′−θ2=arctan2[±1−pzρ′2,−pzρ′]\phi'-\theta_2=arctan2\left[\pm\sqrt{1-\frac{p_z}{\rho'}^2},\frac{-p_z}{\rho'}\right] ϕ′−θ2​=arctan2[±1−ρ′pz​​2​,ρ′−pz​​]

θ2=arctan2(a1+a2C3,a2S3)−arctan2[±1−pzρ′2,−pzρ′]\theta_2=arctan2(a_1+a_2C_3, a_2S_3)-arctan2\left[\pm\sqrt{1-\frac{p_z}{\rho'}^2},\frac{-p_z}{\rho'}\right] θ2​=arctan2(a1​+a2​C3​,a2​S3​)−arctan2[±1−ρ′pz​​2​,ρ′−pz​​]

Jacobian

[dxdydzδxδyδz]=[RobotJacobian][dθ1dθ2dθ3dθ4dθ5dθ6]\left[\begin{matrix} dx\\dy\\dz\\\delta x\\\delta y\\\delta z\end{matrix} \right] = \left[\begin{matrix}\\\\\\Robot\\Jacobian\\\\\\ \end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} d\theta_1\\d\theta_2\\d\theta_3\\d\theta_4\\d\theta_5\\d\theta_6\end{matrix} \right]⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​dxdydzδxδyδz​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​RobotJacobian​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​dθ1​dθ2​dθ3​dθ4​dθ5​dθ6​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​

oror or

[D]=[J][Dθ][D]=[J][D_\theta] [D]=[J][Dθ​]

Forward Jacobian:map the joint velocity of the robot to the end point.
Inverse Jacobian:

Each element in the Jacobian is the derivative of a corresponding kinematic equation with respect to one of the variables.

[pxpypz1]=[equation1equation2equation3equation4]\left[\begin{matrix} p_x\\p_y\\p_z\\1 \end{matrix} \right] = \left[\begin{matrix} equation1\\equation2\\equation3\\equation4 \end{matrix} \right]⎣⎢⎢⎡​px​py​pz​1​⎦⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎡​equation1equation2equation3equation4​⎦⎥⎥⎤​

px=equation1p_x = equation1px​=equation1

dpx=δpxδθ1dθ1+δpxδθ2dθ2+⋯+δpxδθ6dθ6dp_x = \dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_1}d\theta_1+\dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_2}d\theta_2+\cdots+\dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_6}d\theta_6dpx​=δθ1​δpx​​dθ1​+δθ2​δpx​​dθ2​+⋯+δθ6​δpx​​dθ6​

The above method can be used to solve the Jacobian relative to the first frame. But it's only convenient for the first three rows. If the arm is more than 6 dof, we need to use other method.

But in reality, it is much simpler to calulate the Jacobian relative to the the current frame T6T_6T6​ than it is to calculate relative to the first frame. Therefore, we will instead use the following approach.

[T6D]=[T6J][Dθ][^{T_6}D]=[^{T_6}J][D_\theta] [T6​D]=[T6​J][Dθ​]

We can calculate the Jacobian with respect to the last frame using the following formula.

  • The differential motion relationship can be written as:

[T6dxT6dyT6dzT6δxT6δyT6δz]=[T6J11T6J12...T6J16T6J21T6J22...T6J26T6J31T6J32...T6J36T6J41T6J42...T6J46T6J51T6J52...T6J56T6J61T6J62...T6J66][dθ1dθ2dθ3dθ4dθ5dθ6]\left[\begin{matrix} ^{T_6}dx\\^{T_6}dy\\^{T_6}dz\\^{T_6}\delta x\\^{T_6}\delta y\\^{T_6}\delta z\end{matrix} \right] = \left[\begin{matrix} ^{T_6}J_{11} & ^{T_6}J_{12} & . & . & . & ^{T_6}J_{16}\\ ^{T_6}J_{21} & ^{T_6}J_{22} & . & . & . & ^{T_6}J_{26}\\ ^{T_6}J_{31} & ^{T_6}J_{32} & . & . & . & ^{T_6}J_{36}\\ ^{T_6}J_{41} & ^{T_6}J_{42} & . & . & . & ^{T_6}J_{46}\\ ^{T_6}J_{51} & ^{T_6}J_{52} & . & . & . & ^{T_6}J_{56}\\ ^{T_6}J_{61} & ^{T_6}J_{62} & . & . & . & ^{T_6}J_{66} \end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} d\theta_1\\d\theta_2\\d\theta_3\\d\theta_4\\d\theta_5\\d\theta_6\end{matrix} \right]⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​T6​dxT6​dyT6​dzT6​δxT6​δyT6​δz​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​T6​J11​T6​J21​T6​J31​T6​J41​T6​J51​T6​J61​​T6​J12​T6​J22​T6​J32​T6​J42​T6​J52​T6​J62​​......​......​......​T6​J16​T6​J26​T6​J36​T6​J46​T6​J56​T6​J66​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​dθ1​dθ2​dθ3​dθ4​dθ5​dθ6​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​

  • Assuming that any combination of A1A2...AnA_1A_2...A_nA1​A2​...An​ can be expressed with a corresponding n,o,a,pn,o,a,pn,o,a,p matrix, the corresponding elements of the matrix will be used to calculate the Jacobian.
  • If joint iii under consideration is a revolute joint, then:

T6J1i=(−nxpy+nypx)T6J2i=(−oxpy+oypx)T6J3i=(−axpy+aypx)T6J4i=nzT6J5i=ozT6J6i=az\begin{array}{ccc} ^{T_6}J_{1i}=(-n_xp_y+n_yp_x) & ^{T_6}J_{2i}=(-o_xp_y+o_yp_x) & ^{T_6}J_{3i}=(-a_xp_y+a_yp_x) \\ ^{T_6}J_{4i}=n_z & ^{T_6}J_{5i}=o_z & ^{T_6}J_{6i}=a_z \end{array}T6​J1i​=(−nx​py​+ny​px​)T6​J4i​=nz​​T6​J2i​=(−ox​py​+oy​px​)T6​J5i​=oz​​T6​J3i​=(−ax​py​+ay​px​)T6​J6i​=az​​

  • If joint iii under consideration is a prismatic joint, then:

T6J1i=nzT6J2i=ozT6J3i=azT6J4i=0T6J5i=0T6J6i=0\begin{array}{ccc} ^{T_6}J_{1i}=n_z & ^{T_6}J_{2i}=o_z & ^{T_6}J_{3i}=a_z \\ ^{T_6}J_{4i}=0 & ^{T_6}J_{5i}=0 & ^{T_6}J_{6i}=0 \end{array}T6​J1i​=nz​T6​J4i​=0​T6​J2i​=oz​T6​J5i​=0​T6​J3i​=az​T6​J6i​=0​

  • For Equation (1) and (2), for column iii use i−1T6^{i-1}T_6i−1T6​, meaning:
    For column 1, use 0T6=A1A2A3A4A5A6^0T_6=A_1A_2A_3A_4A_5A_60T6​=A1​A2​A3​A4​A5​A6​
    For column 2, use 1T6=A2A3A4A5A6^1T_6=A_2A_3A_4A_5A_61T6​=A2​A3​A4​A5​A6​
    For column 3, use 2T6=A3A4A5A6^2T_6=A_3A_4A_5A_62T6​=A3​A4​A5​A6​
    For column 4, use 3T6=A4A5A6^3T_6=A_4A_5A_63T6​=A4​A5​A6​
    For column 5, use 4T6=A5A6^4T_6=A_5A_64T6​=A5​A6​
    For column 6, use 5T6=A6^5T_6=A_65T6​=A6​

Jacobian Modeling

For the legs in the left side:

[pxpypz1]=[dS1+a1C1C2+a2C1C23−dC1+a1S1C2+a2S1C23a1S2+a2S231]\left[ \begin{matrix} p_x\\ p_y\\ p_z\\ 1 \end{matrix} \right] = \left[ \begin{matrix} dS_1 + a_1C_1C_2 + a_2C_1C_{23}\\ -dC_1 + a_1S_1C_2 + a_2S_1C_{23}\\ a_1S_2 + a_2S_{23}\\ 1 \end{matrix} \right] ⎣⎢⎢⎡​px​py​pz​1​⎦⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎡​dS1​+a1​C1​C2​+a2​C1​C23​−dC1​+a1​S1​C2​+a2​S1​C23​a1​S2​+a2​S23​1​⎦⎥⎥⎤​

px=dS1+a1C1C2+a2C1C23=dsin(θ1)+a1cos(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpxδθ1=dcos(θ1)−a1sin(θ1)cos(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpxδθ2=−a1cos(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)δpxδθ3=−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)\begin{aligned} p_x&=dS_1 + a_1C_1C_2 + a_2C_1C_{23}\\ &=dsin(\theta_1)+a_1cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_1}&=dcos(\theta_1)-a_1sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_2}&=-a_1cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_3}&=-a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \end{aligned}px​δθ1​δpx​​δθ2​δpx​​δθ3​δpx​​​=dS1​+a1​C1​C2​+a2​C1​C23​=dsin(θ1​)+a1​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=dcos(θ1​)−a1​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=−a1​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)=−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)​

py=−dC1+a1S1C2+a2S1C23=−dcos(θ1)+a1sin(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2sin(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpyδθ1=dsin(θ1)+a1cos(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpyδθ2=−a1sin(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)δpyδθ3=−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)\begin{aligned} p_y&=-dC_1 + a_1S_1C_2 + a_2S_1C_{23}\\ &=-dcos(\theta_1)+a_1sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_1}&=dsin(\theta_1)+a_1cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_2}&=-a_1sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_3}&=-a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \end{aligned}py​δθ1​δpy​​δθ2​δpy​​δθ3​δpy​​​=−dC1​+a1​S1​C2​+a2​S1​C23​=−dcos(θ1​)+a1​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=dsin(θ1​)+a1​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=−a1​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)=−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)​

pz=a1S2+a2S23=a1sin(θ2)+a2sin(θ2+θ3)δpzδθ1=0δpzδθ2=a1cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ2+θ3)δpzδθ3=a2cos(θ2+θ3)\begin{aligned} p_z&=a_1S_2 + a_2S_{23}\\ &=a_1sin(\theta_2)+a_2sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_1}&=0\\ \frac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_2}&=a_1cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_3}&=a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \end{aligned}pz​δθ1​δpz​​δθ2​δpz​​δθ3​δpz​​​=a1​S2​+a2​S23​=a1​sin(θ2​)+a2​sin(θ2​+θ3​)=0=a1​cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)=a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)​

Therefore, the Jacobian matrix for the legs in the left side is:

J=[δpxδθ1δpxδθ2δpxδθ3δpyδθ1δpyδθ2δpyδθ3δpzδθ1δpzδθ2δpzδθ3]=[dcos(θ1)−a1sin(θ1)cos(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)−a1cos(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)dsin(θ1)+a1cos(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)−a1sin(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)0a1cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ2+θ3)a2cos(θ2+θ3)]\begin{aligned} J&= \left[ \begin{matrix} \dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_1} & \dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_2} & \dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_3}\\ \dfrac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_1} & \dfrac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_2} & \dfrac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_3}\\ \dfrac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_1} & \dfrac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_2} & \dfrac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_3} \end{matrix} \right]\\ &= \left[ \begin{matrix} dcos(\theta_1)-a_1sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_1cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ dsin(\theta_1)+a_1cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_1sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ 0 & a_1cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) & a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned}J​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​δθ1​δpx​​δθ1​δpy​​δθ1​δpz​​​δθ2​δpx​​δθ2​δpy​​δθ2​δpz​​​δθ3​δpx​​δθ3​δpy​​δθ3​δpz​​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎡​dcos(θ1​)−a1​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)dsin(θ1​)+a1​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)0​−a1​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)−a1​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)a1​cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)​−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)​⎦⎤​​

For the legs in right side:

[pxpypz1]=[−dS1+a1C1C2+a2C1C23dC1+a1S1C2+a2S1C23−a1S2−a2S231]\left[ \begin{matrix} p_x\\ p_y\\ p_z\\ 1 \end{matrix} \right] = \left[ \begin{matrix} -dS_1 + a_1C_1C_2 + a_2C_1C_{23}\\ dC_1 + a_1S_1C_2 + a_2S_1C_{23}\\ -a_1S_2 - a_2S_{23}\\ 1 \end{matrix} \right] ⎣⎢⎢⎡​px​py​pz​1​⎦⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎢⎢⎡​−dS1​+a1​C1​C2​+a2​C1​C23​dC1​+a1​S1​C2​+a2​S1​C23​−a1​S2​−a2​S23​1​⎦⎥⎥⎤​

px=−dS1+a1C1C2+a2C1C23=−dsin(θ1)+a1cos(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpxδθ1=−dcos(θ1)−a1sin(θ1)cos(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpxδθ2=−a1cos(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)δpxδθ3=−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)\begin{aligned} p_x&=-dS_1 + a_1C_1C_2 + a_2C_1C_{23}\\ &=-dsin(\theta_1)+a_1cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_1}&=-dcos(\theta_1)-a_1sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_2}&=-a_1cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_3}&=-a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \end{aligned}px​δθ1​δpx​​δθ2​δpx​​δθ3​δpx​​​=−dS1​+a1​C1​C2​+a2​C1​C23​=−dsin(θ1​)+a1​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=−dcos(θ1​)−a1​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=−a1​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)=−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)​

py=dC1+a1S1C2+a2S1C23=dcos(θ1)+a1sin(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2sin(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpyδθ1=−dsin(θ1)+a1cos(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)δpyδθ2=−a1sin(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)δpyδθ3=−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)\begin{aligned} p_y&=dC_1 + a_1S_1C_2 + a_2S_1C_{23}\\ &=dcos(\theta_1)+a_1sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_1}&=-dsin(\theta_1)+a_1cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_2}&=-a_1sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_3}&=-a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \end{aligned}py​δθ1​δpy​​δθ2​δpy​​δθ3​δpy​​​=dC1​+a1​S1​C2​+a2​S1​C23​=dcos(θ1​)+a1​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=−dsin(θ1​)+a1​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)=−a1​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)=−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)​

pz=−a1S2−a2S23=−a1sin(θ2)−a2sin(θ2+θ3)δpzδθ1=0δpzδθ2=−a1cos(θ2)−a2cos(θ2+θ3)δpzδθ3=−a2cos(θ2+θ3)\begin{aligned} p_z&=-a_1S_2 - a_2S_{23}\\ &=-a_1sin(\theta_2) - a_2sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_1}&=0\\ \frac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_2}&=-a_1cos(\theta_2)-a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \frac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_3}&=-a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ \end{aligned}pz​δθ1​δpz​​δθ2​δpz​​δθ3​δpz​​​=−a1​S2​−a2​S23​=−a1​sin(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ2​+θ3​)=0=−a1​cos(θ2​)−a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)=−a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)​

Therefore, the Jacobian matrix for the legs in the right side is:

J=[δpxδθ1δpxδθ2δpxδθ3δpyδθ1δpyδθ2δpyδθ3δpzδθ1δpzδθ2δpzδθ3]=[−dcos(θ1)−a1sin(θ1)cos(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)−a1cos(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)−a2cos(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)−dsin(θ1)+a1cos(θ1)cos(θ2)+a2cos(θ1)cos(θ2+θ3)−a1sin(θ1)sin(θ2)−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)−a2sin(θ1)sin(θ2+θ3)0−a1cos(θ2)−a2cos(θ2+θ3)−a2cos(θ2+θ3)]\begin{aligned} J&= \left[ \begin{matrix} \dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_1} & \dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_2} & \dfrac{\delta p_x}{\delta \theta_3}\\ \dfrac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_1} & \dfrac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_2} & \dfrac{\delta p_y}{\delta \theta_3}\\ \dfrac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_1} & \dfrac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_2} & \dfrac{\delta p_z}{\delta \theta_3} \end{matrix} \right]\\ &= \left[ \begin{matrix} -dcos(\theta_1)-a_1sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_1cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_2cos(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ -dsin(\theta_1)+a_1cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2)+a_2cos(\theta_1)cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_1sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2)-a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_2sin(\theta_1)sin(\theta_2+\theta_3)\\ 0 & -a_1cos(\theta_2)-a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) & -a_2cos(\theta_2+\theta_3) \end{matrix} \right] \end{aligned}J​=⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎡​δθ1​δpx​​δθ1​δpy​​δθ1​δpz​​​δθ2​δpx​​δθ2​δpy​​δθ2​δpz​​​δθ3​δpx​​δθ3​δpy​​δθ3​δpz​​​⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎤​=⎣⎡​−dcos(θ1​)−a1​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)−dsin(θ1​)+a1​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​)+a2​cos(θ1​)cos(θ2​+θ3​)0​−a1​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)−a1​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​)−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)−a1​cos(θ2​)−a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)​−a2​cos(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)−a2​sin(θ1​)sin(θ2​+θ3​)−a2​cos(θ2​+θ3​)​⎦⎤​​

Actually we can use matlab to solve the jacobian matrix very quickly and easily. sym/jacobian
